mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring the Influence of Climate Modes on Extremes Related to Atmospheric Fronts along the Eastern United States

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Atmospheric fronts are responsible for changes in temperature, precipitation, and wind direction, and are often associated with extremes related to the weather, such as cold snaps and flooding, that have significant socio-economic impacts. Winter cold fronts moving across the eastern United States are known to leave residents in states of extreme cold and dangerous weather. These temperatures can lead to an increase in electricity demand, which can result in increased carbon emissions. With several states working to reduce carbon emissions, a better understanding and predictability of fronts and their temperature change impacts would help power companies better budget for carbon emissions and guide capital investment in renewable technologies. In this research, we analyze how several leading modes of climate variability, such as the NAO, PNA and ENSO, influence temperature extremes related to the passing of atmospheric fronts. This manuscript investigates the average temperature anomalies associated with the passage cold and warm fronts for locations in North Carolina, New York, Florida, and off the coast of Florida. Several characteristic patterns defining the passage of fronts in each location have been discussed. With these anomalies characterized, they were compared to the average temperature anomalies associated with cold fronts during the positive and negative phases of the NAO, PNA, and ENSO. The modes were found to influence the characteristic anomalies surrounding cold fronts. Each mode impacted every location differently, but they could cause or suppress extreme temperatures as they related to the passage of cold fronts. A preliminary exploration of the relationship between electricity demand and the passage of cold fronts was also discussed. The influence of frontal strength on spikes in electricity demand was found to result in a higher probability for larger spikes in demand with stronger cold fronts and a lower probability for spikes with weaker fronts. The location in New York was selected to analyze how cold fronts during ENSO may change this relationship that was found between cold fronts and electricity demand spikes. This preliminary investigation proved that there is a relationship between electricity demand spikes and cold fronts and that the modes of variability can impact this relationship. This provides potential for more extensive work to be done in the future to fully quantify the scale relationship between fronts and electricity demand during specific phases of modes of variability.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Atmospheric Fronts, Climate, Energy demand, Meteorology
Rhys Parfitt, Professor Directing Thesis; Robert Hart, Committee Member; Philip Sura, Committee Member; Matthew Carter, Committee Member.
